comments.author: Karen Burden
comments.content: I believe it’s worse than they think. I believe it may never be killed off in the body. Since people are getting re-diagnosed with it again, I believe it’s like a herpes virus, or sty virus, that it always stays with you, only going dormant. But any time the immune system is down/flinches, it flares up again. If I’m right, this is troubling. as it will also have so many chances to mutate, not good. Also, the length of time it lasts on surfaces, and the fact that people can have it without symptoms for a good while etc. hmm.. it’s so problematic on so many levels. The world will need to sacrifice their economies, accept a downturn, and declare a world travel ban. Tough times,  tough decisions,  tough measures, or alternatively accept there will be high casualties. I hope the medical world works on a cure in collaboration, not competition. Not everything can be about money.

comments.author: Q Min
comments.content: At Brampton Civic hospital in Ontario, they have new screening questions patients answer on kiosks when they register. And signage posted here and there. The ER is packed to the brim, and they are always in a state of extreme gridlock. What will staff do should someone walk in with Covid19. Also, a GP office said if someone presents with cough + fever + recent travel, they tell them to go to the ER. Meanwhile, Ontario public health officials have said NOT to go to ERs unless you call ahead to let them know youre coming. Or call your local Public  Health for instruction. I see public and staff openly cough in waiting rooms, Not wearing masks that are provided to them. Is Brampton prepared?
